entry.title: Archiving Enterprise Projects (EPPM) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Enterprise Portfolio and Project Management (EPPM) projects can accumulate over time. Closed or obsolete projects that remain in the system increase data volume and negatively affect reporting clarity and system performance.

In addition, there are practical scenarios where projects are created incorrectly and already moved to status Released — for example, due to wrong organizational assignments, incorrect project profiles, or test creations in productive systems. Since such projects cannot simply be deleted once released, archiving becomes the only compliant way to remove them from operational usage.

In this blog post, I will show how to archive Enterprise Projects using the ILM-enabled archiving object /S4PPM/PRO , including prerequisites, ILM configuration, archiving execution, monitoring, and optional data destruction.

1. Prerequisites 

1.1. Required scope item

Archiving of Enterprise Projects is available only if the following scope item is activated:

  • 1KA – Information Lifecycle Management 

  • 1NT – Project Control - Finance 

1.2. Required user roles

Ensure that your user has the following roles assigned:

Business RoleBusiness Role ID
Project Financial ControllerSAP_BR_PROJ_FIN_CONTROLLER
Configuration Expert – Business Process ConfigurationSAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT

If you don’t have the required roles, contact your administrator or refer to the Maintain Business Users app.

1.3. Functional prerequisites for EPPM projects

An Enterprise Project can only be archived if all of the following conditions are met:

  • The project status is Closed

  • A residence period is defined and has ended
    (controlled via ILM policies, described below)

  • No assigned orders exist (sales orders, purchase orders, etc.)

  • No actual cost postings exist

  • No attachments (assigned documents) exist

If any assigned orders, actual postings, or attachments exist for the project or its WBS elements, these objects must be archived first.

1.4 ILM configuration prerequisites

To enable archiving of Enterprise Projects, several ILM-related configuration steps must be completed.

1.4.1 Maintain Audit Area

An audit area is a logical grouping of one or more ILM objects based on a specific business purpose. These objects can be retrieved for various audit-related scenarios, such as tax or financial audits, as well as warranty and product liability claims.

Audit areas are a mandatory prerequisite for defining ILM policies. An ILM object must be assigned to an audit area before residence or retention rules can be created.

To define an Audit Area, log on to SAP Central Business Configuration.
Open the Configuration app and search for the configuration activity Maintain Audit Area. Open the activity to access the audit area maintenance screen.

 

In the Maintain Audit Area configuration, choose Edit and then select New Entries. Enter the Audit Area technical name, provide a meaningful Description, and select the appropriate Policy Category.

The Policy Category defines how data lifecycle rules are applied:

  • Retention Rules specify the minimum and maximum time data must be retained, including the relevant time reference and optional offsets. These rules are typically driven by legal or regulatory requirements.

  • Residence Rules specify how long data must remain in the database before it becomes eligible for archiving, based on a defined residence duration and time reference.

Selecting the correct policy category is critical because it determines which ILM rules can be maintained later. In practice, residence rules control when Enterprise Projects can be archived, while retention rules control how long archived data must be kept before deletion.

After entering all required fields, save your changes. The audit area is now available for assigning ILM objects and for maintaining ILM policies and rules in subsequent configuration st

1.4.2 Assign ILM Object to Audit Area

At this step, you need to assign an ILM object to an audit area. This is a mandatory prerequisite for maintaining ILM policies and rules and for enabling archiving of the corresponding business object.

To assign an ILM object to an Audit Area, log on to SAP Central Business Configuration.
Open the Configuration app and search for the configuration activity Assign ILM Object to Audit Area. Open the activity to proceed with the assignment.

In the Assign ILM Object to Audit Area configuration, select the relevant Policy Category and Audit Area, and then choose Run.

On the next screen, switch to Edit mode and select New Entries. Enter the ILM object /S4PPM/PRO and set the Status to Active, then save your entry.

The archiving object /S4PPM/PRO is responsible for archiving Enterprise Projects and includes the following data:

  • Project header data (including milestones, entitlements, and status values)

  • WBS elements

  • Planned costs (at both project and WBS level)

  • Change documents

Repeat this step for both previously defined Audit Areas — one with the Policy Category Retention Rules and one with the Policy Category Residence Rules — to ensure that both retention and residence policies can be evaluated for the Enterprise Project archiving object.

If you need to adjust an existing assignment, select the corresponding entry, choose Edit, update the Status as required (for example, set it to Inactive), and save the changes.

1.4.3 Maintain ILM Policies and Rules

At this step, you define ILM policies and rules that control how long Enterprise Project data must remain in the system and when it becomes eligible for archiving or destruction. Policies and rules are maintained per ILM object and Audit Area and are a mandatory prerequisite for ILM-based archiving.

To maintain ILM policies and rules, log on to SAP Central Business Configuration.
Open the Configuration app and search for the configuration activity Maintain ILM Policies and Rules. Open the activity to proceed with the policy maintenance.

In the configuration screen, select the relevant ILM Object, Policy Category (Residence Rules), and Audit Area, and then choose Run.

On the next screen, switch to Edit mode and select New Entries to create a new ILM policy. Enter a Policy Name and Status.

When creating the policy, ensure that the Status is set to Not Live. Only policies with status Not Live can be customized, allowing you to define condition fields and maintain residence or retention rules.

After all rules have been defined and reviewed, the policy status can be changed to Live to activate it.

After creating the ILM policy, you can define Condition Fields. Condition fields allow you to control which Enterprise Projects the ILM rules apply to, based on specific project attributes.

To maintain condition fields, select Condition Fields in the Dialog Structure on the left-hand side.

In the Condition Fields section, choose New Entries and define the condition fields that should be evaluated when the ILM rules are applied. Each condition field is maintained with a Position, which determines the evaluation order of the conditions.

For the archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, SAP provides several available condition fields, such as:

  • Project Profile

  • Company Code

  • Profit Center

  • Responsible Cost Center

  • Plant

In our example, Project Profile (PROFILEID) is used as a condition field. This allows you to define different residence or retention rules depending on the project profile, for example distinguishing between overhead, investment, or statistical projects.

After defining the condition fields, you need to maintain Residence Rules for the ILM policy. Residence rules determine how long an Enterprise Project must remain in the database before it becomes eligible for archiving.

To define residence rules, select Residence Rules in the Dialog Structure on the left-hand side and switch to Edit mode. Choose New Entries to create a new rule.

For each residence rule, maintain the following fields:

  • Residence Period – defines the length of time the project must remain in the database before archiving is allowed. The residence period is evaluated together with the time reference and time unit.

  • Time Unit – specifies the unit of the residence period, such as days, months, or years.

  • Time Reference – determines the event in the project lifecycle that serves as the starting point for the residence period. For the archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, a common time reference is Date of Last Change (CHANGE_DATE).

  • Time Offset – allows you to shift the start date of the residence period to the end of a calendar unit, such as the end of a month, quarter, or year.

  • Rule Number – a system-assigned identifier used to uniquely identify the rule.

  • Priority – defines the precedence of the rule when multiple rules apply. Higher values indicate higher priority. If no priority is maintained, the default value is 0.

Once saved, the residence rule ensures that Enterprise Projects cannot be archived until the defined residence period has fully expired. This mechanism helps meet legal and operational requirements by preventing premature archiving of project data.

After defining the residence rule itself, you can further refine its scope by maintaining Condition Field Values. This step allows you to specify for which Enterprise Projects the rule applies, based on the condition fields defined earlier.

To maintain condition field values, select Condition Field Values under Residence Rules in the Dialog Structure on the left-hand side.

In this example, the condition field Project Profile (PROFILEID) is restricted to the values YP02 (Investment Project) and YP03 (Overhead Project).

After maintaining the required values, activate and save your entries. The residence rule will now be applied only to Enterprise Projects that match both the rule definition and the specified condition field values.

After maintaining and activating the residence rules, you can define Retention Rules. Retention rules determine how long archived Enterprise Project data must be retained and when it becomes eligible for destruction, in accordance with legal and compliance requirements.

In the configuration screen, select the relevant ILM Object (/S4PPM/PRO), change the Policy Category to Retention Rules, select the appropriate Audit Area, and then choose Run.

On the next screen, switch to Edit mode and select New Entries to create a new ILM policy. Enter a Policy Name and Status.

When creating the policy, ensure that the Status is set to Not Live. Only policies with status Not Live can be customized, allowing you to define condition fields and maintain residence or retention rules.

After all rules have been defined and reviewed, the policy status can be changed to Live to activate it.

After creating the ILM policy, you can define Condition Fields. Condition fields allow you to control which Enterprise Projects the ILM rules apply to, based on specific project attributes.

To maintain condition fields, select Condition Fields in the Dialog Structure on the left-hand side.

In the Condition Fields section, choose New Entries and define the condition fields that should be evaluated when the ILM rules are applied. Each condition field is maintained with a Position, which determines the evaluation order of the conditions.

For the archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, SAP provides several available condition fields, such as:

  • Project Profile

  • Company Code

  • Profit Center

  • Responsible Cost Center

  • Plant

In our example, Project Profile (PROFILEID) is used as a condition field. This allows you to define different residence or retention rules depending on the project profile, for example distinguishing between overhead, investment, or statistical projects.

After defining the condition fields, you need to maintain Retention Rules for the ILM policy. Retention rules determine how long archived Enterprise Project data must be retained and when it becomes eligible for mandatory destruction.

To define retention rules, select Retention Rules in the Dialog Structure on the left-hand side and switch to Edit mode. Choose New Entries to create a new rule.

For each retention rule, maintain the following fields:

  • Authorization Group – defines which users are allowed to display archived project data during the retention period. The authorization group must be maintained in the Maintain Authorization Groups for ILM Blocking configuration activity and is used together with the restriction type BLOCKED_DATA.

  • Minimum Retention Period – defines the minimum duration for which archived Enterprise Project data must be retained. The data cannot be deleted before this period has expired. The minimum retention period is evaluated together with the time reference and time unit.

  • Maximum Retention Period – defines the maximum duration for which archived data may be retained. Once this period expires, the data becomes eligible for mandatory destruction.

  • Time Unit – specifies the unit for both minimum and maximum retention periods, such as days, months, or years.

  • Time Reference – determines the event in the project lifecycle that serves as the starting point for the retention period. For the archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, a common time reference is Date of Last Change (CHANGE_DATE).

  • Time Offset – allows you to shift the start date of the retention period to the end of a calendar unit, such as the end of a month, quarter, or year. This adjusted date is used as the basis for calculating the retention period.

  • Priority – defines the precedence of the rule when multiple retention rules apply. Higher values indicate higher priority. If no priority is maintained, the default value is 0.

Once saved, the retention rule ensures that archived Enterprise Project data is retained for the legally or operationally required period and is only deleted after the defined maximum retention period has expired. This mechanism helps ensure compliance with legal, audit, and data protection requirements.

After defining the retention rule itself, you can further refine its scope by maintaining Condition Field Values. This step allows you to specify for which Enterprise Projects the retention rule applies, based on the condition fields defined earlier in the policy.

To maintain condition field values, select Condition Field Values under Retention Rules in the Dialog Structure on the left-hand side.

In this example, the condition field Project Profile (PROFILEID) is restricted to the values YP02 (Investment Project) and YP03 (Overhead Project). This means that the retention rule will only be evaluated for Enterprise Projects that use one of these two project profiles.

After maintaining the required values, save and activate your entries. The retention rule will now be applied only to Enterprise Projects that match both the retention rule definition and the specified condition field values.

2. Archiving Execution

Once all prerequisites are fulfilled — including Enterprise Project status checks and the required ILM configuration — you can proceed with the archiving execution. This phase covers the technical steps required to select eligible projects, run the archiving jobs, and optionally perform data destruction after retention periods expire.

2.1. Manage Archiving Variants and Schedule Archiving Jobs

Use the Manage Archiving Variants app (F0627A) to define which Enterprise Projects should be included in the archiving run.

In the Archiving Objects list on the left-hand side, select Enterprise Projects with the archiving object /S4PPM/PRO. This object represents Enterprise Projects and is used to control their archiving process.

The main screen displays an overview of the selected archiving object, including the last archive run date and the current status of archiving runs. At this point, no runs or variants exist yet, which is why no data is shown.

To proceed, choose Add New Variant in the bottom-right corner of the screen.

Variant Details

  • Name – technical name of the variant. It uniquely identifies the archiving configuration and is mandatory.
  • Description – optional text used to document the purpose of the archiving variant.
  • Variant Type – defines the type of the variant. For Enterprise Projects, the following options are available: 
    • Write – executes the actual archiving run and creates archive files. This variant type is required to archive Enterprise Project data.
    • Preprocessing – performs a preliminary check to determine which projects are eligible for archiving, without archiving any data. It is typically used for validation before executing the write phase.
  • Application Detail Log – controls the level of detail written to the application log. The Complete option is recommended for full transparency and troubleshooting.
  • Test Mode – when enabled, the archiving run is executed in simulation mode. No data is archived, but all checks are performed.
  • Action – defines the operation executed by the variant.
    • Archiving – archives Enterprise Project data.
    • Data Destruction – permanently deletes archived data.

Selection Parameters

  • Project Definition – restricts the archiving run to specific Enterprise Projects.
  • Company Code – limits archiving to projects belonging to a specific company code.
  • Plant – optional restriction based on plant.
  • Profit Center – optional restriction based on profit center.
  • Archiving Session Note – optional field used to document the archiving session.

After maintaining all required fields, choose Save. The archiving variant is now available to schedule and monitor archiving jobs for Enterprise Projects.

 

After saving the variant, return to the previous screen and open the All Variants tab.

On this screen, all archiving variants created for the selected archiving object /S4PPM/PRO (Enterprise Projects) are displayed. You can review each variant’s name, description, and type (for example, Write).

To continue with archiving execution, select the required variant from the list and click the arrow (>) on the right-hand side. This opens the variant details, where you can schedule the archiving run and later monitor its execution status.

On the variant details screen, review the selection parameters and execution settings one final time.

To start the archiving run, click Schedule Archiving at the bottom of the screen. This action schedules an archiving job for the selected variant ARCHIVING_1, based on the defined criteria (for example, Project Definition, Company Code, Plant, or Profit Center).

In the Schedule Archiving dialog, review the technical details of the archiving run.

The system displays the Archiving Object /S4PPM/PRO and the selected Write Variant ARCHIVING_1. These fields are derived from the variant configuration and cannot be changed at this stage.

To confirm and start the archiving run, click Schedule. This action creates a background archiving job for Enterprise Projects based on the defined selection parameters and ILM rules.

Scheduled archiving runs in the production mode are triggered by a technical job which is executed every two days at 20:00 UTC whereas scheduled archiving runs in the test mode are triggered by a technical job which is executed every two hours.

2.2. Monitor Archiving Jobs

After scheduling the archiving run, you can monitor its execution using the Monitor Archiving Jobs (F0510A) app.

This app provides a centralized overview of all archiving jobs for the selected archiving object and allows you to track their execution status and analyze potential issues.

In this screen, you can see an overview of all archiving jobs for the Enterprise Projects archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, grouped by their current status:

  • Scheduled – jobs that are planned but not yet started

  • In Process – jobs currently running

  • Completed – successfully finished jobs

  • Failed – jobs that ended with errors

In the example shown, a Write Job based on the variant ARCHIVING_1 is currently in the Scheduled status. The job has been triggered by the user and is waiting for execution by the system background scheduler.

Once the archiving job has finished processing, it moves to the Completed status.

In this screen, you can see all successfully executed jobs, grouped under Completed jobs. Each entry represents a technical step of the archiving process, such as:

  • Write Job – selects the Enterprise Projects based on the archiving variant and writes the eligible data to the archive files

  • Storage Job – stores the generated archive files in the configured ILM storage

  • Delete Job – removes archived data from the database, if deletion is part of the execution scope

By selecting the arrow (>) icon at the end of a job row, you can drill down into the job details to review application logs and technical messages. This step is essential to confirm that the archiving process for Enterprise Projects has completed successfully and without errors.

After opening a completed Write Job, you can analyze the execution results using the following tabs:

Job Details
This tab provides a structured overview of the archiving run configuration and execution context. It includes the Variant and Variant Description used for the run, execution-related information (such as start time and duration), and the Archiving Session number that uniquely identifies the created archiving session.

Job Log
The Job Log contains the technical execution log of the background job. It shows a chronological sequence of processing steps, including job start, execution of the write program /S4PPM/PROJECT_WRITE creation of the archiving session, generation of archive files, and job completion.

Application Log
The Application Log shows business-level messages generated during the archiving run. It lists which Enterprise Projects were processed, how many objects were archived, and whether the processing was successful or not. This tab is the most relevant for functional verification, as it confirms that the intended projects (for example, specific project definitions or WBS structures) were actually archived.

Together, these three tabs allow you to fully validate both the technical execution and the business outcome of the Enterprise Project archiving run.

2.3. ILM Data Destruction

After Enterprise Projects have been successfully archived and all retention periods have expired, the archived data can be permanently deleted using ILM Data Destruction.

ILM Data Destruction is the final step in the Information Lifecycle Management process. It physically removes archived data from the ILM store and therefore cannot be reversed. For this reason, this step must be performed strictly in accordance with legal, compliance, and internal governance requirements.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, ILM Data Destruction is executed using the ILM Data Destruction (F2662) app.

After opening the app, navigate to the Archive Files tab.

On this tab, the system displays all ILM-enabled archiving objects that have archived data eligible for data destruction. Each entry represents an archiving object for which archive files exist in the ILM store.

Locate the Enterprise Projects archiving object /S4PPM/PRO in the list. The Expired Resources column shows the number of archive files whose maximum retention period has expired and which are therefore eligible for permanent deletion.

Select the entry for /S4PPM/PRO and use the navigation arrow (>) to drill down into the list of expired archive files. This step allows you to review which archive files are available for data destruction before proceeding with the deletion process.

After opening the Enterprise Projects archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, the app displays the Resources tab with all archive files that are eligible for data destruction.

In this screen, you can see the list of Expired Resources, including the archive file ID, the Expiration Date, and the Mandatory Destruction Date. The expiration date indicates when the maximum retention period has ended, while the mandatory destruction date defines the latest point in time by which the data must be permanently deleted to comply with legal requirements.

Select the relevant archive file by marking the checkbox and choose Schedule. This action schedules the data destruction job for the selected archive file. Once scheduled and executed, the archive file will be permanently removed from the ILM store and cannot be restored.

After selecting the expired archive file and choosing Schedule, the Schedule Delete dialog is displayed.

In this dialog, the system warns that the selected data will be deleted permanently. Optionally, you can enable Test Mode to simulate the deletion without physically removing the data, which is useful for validation and compliance checks.
To proceed with irreversible data destruction, choose Delete. This schedules the data destruction job and permanently removes the archive file from the ILM store once executed.

After the deletion job has been executed successfully, the archive file is removed from the ILM store and no longer appears in the list of expired resources.

At this point, the Resources view is empty for the selected ILM object, which confirms that the data destruction has been completed successfully.
This indicates the final stage of the Information Lifecycle Management process: the archived Enterprise Project data has been permanently deleted and cannot be recovered.

Summary

In this blog post, we explored how to archive and permanently delete Enterprise Projects in SAP S/4HANA Cloud using the Information Lifecycle Management (ILM) framework.

We walked through the complete end-to-end process: preparing the prerequisites, configuring ILM audit areas and policies, assigning the archiving object /S4PPM/PRO, and executing archiving runs using archiving variants. We then reviewed how to monitor archiving jobs and analyze their logs to ensure successful execution.

Finally, we covered the ILM Data Destruction step, where archived project data is permanently deleted once retention periods have expired, completing the lifecycle in a compliant and controlled manner.

This approach helps keep the system clean, ensures compliance with legal retention requirements, and provides a structured and auditable way to manage the full lifecycle of Enterprise Project data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

entry.title: GST Partner needs additional fields for MM and FI invoice booking - India GST requirement
entry.content:
Hi, this question is related to the GST Partner field available in MIRO and FB60 screen allowing Accounts Payable to capture the GST Partner Vendor Number in a dedicated field when the invoicing vendor is different. We have a scenario in Imports where the Shipping Liner raises a GST invoice against Company A but the invoice is sent by a Clearing House Agent (CHA) as a reimbursement charge. Company A need to pay to the CHA and not to the Shipping Liner, however for GST recons, we also need to capture the original invoice details from the Shipping Liner invoice. We are using the GST Partner field in MIRO/FB60 to capture the Shipping Liner vendor code. However, there is no dedicated field to capture the Invoice Number and Invoice date from the Shipping Liner invoice.

I would like to understand what is SAP recommended process or the generally accepted process of booking such invoices in India GST reconciliation context?

entry.title: From Hype to Hands-On: Level Up Your AI Skills This December
entry.content:
In the age of AI, the skills we build today will define how we work tomorrow. That’s why we’ve launched a monthly series of blogs that spotlight the latest AI learning assets and upcoming learning opportunities.

Building on my first blog, where I introduced you to our AI live sessions Beyond Hype (which is all about getting productive with SAP Business AI), let me follow up with you on your most asked questions:

  1. What are the prerequisites to set up a Generative AI hub?
    In short, you need to enable SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad in the SAP BTP Cockpit and connect them. That means that you need to add both products to your sub account and run the booster, a set of guided, interactive steps that enable you to select, configure, and consume services on SAP BTP. Follow the steps explained in the SAP Discovery Center Mission to Set Up SAP AI Core Generative AI Hub. If you only want to test the Generative AI hub, you can try it now for 30 days. 

    Watch the video to find out more about benchmark engineering and see a demo of prompt optimizer in Generative AI hub.

     

  2. How can I get started with SAP-RPT-1?
    In case you haven’t heard, SAP has announced its first enterprise relational foundation model (RPT), SAP-RPT-1, along with a no-code testing playground environment. SAP-RPT-1 enables analytical and predictive tasks on structured business data using in-context learning, allowing classification and regression directly via example records in an API call. Grounded in verified enterprise data, it delivers reliable, fact-based predictions without requiring customers to train or manage models. Read more about why this is A New Paradigm for Enterprise AI: In-Context Learning for Relational Data by Dr. Philipp Herzig, Chief Technology Officer at SAP.

    Do you know you can get started with SAP-RPT-1 immediately? There is a web-based testing SAP-RPT playground environment where, at no cost, you can experience the model performance and the model’s in-context learning capabilities without any coding, utilizing your own data or SAP-provided example datasets. If you want to use your own data, simply upload your CSV or use our sample data files, run real-world scenarios, and see instant insights from your business data with no setup or coding required. Try it now!

    Check out the video to learn more about the latest innovation in SAP Business AI and see SAP-RPT-1 predict a sales price for a house.

     

  3. Could you please share the learning materials to help us learn more and become certified?
    A great starting point is SAP Learning, where you can find an overview of AI-guided learning journeys, documentation, live sessions, and certifications tailored to your preferences.

    Do you know that SAP announced its reimagined certification strategy at this year's SAP TechEd, transitioning from a traditional proctored multiple-choice exam to a comprehensive practical assessment model that reflects real-world work scenarios? Learners can use resources like the SAP Help Portal and AI tools such as SAP Joule for Consultants, just as they would on the job. This shift ensures certifications recognize not only what you know, but how you apply it. To help you prepare for the practical assessment, every learning journey is equipped with a practical exercise to provide hands-on experience.

    To learn more about the content covered in the sessions, the two certifications are a great source of learning: SAP Generative AI Developer or SAP Build Developer (covering Joule Studio). Also, don’t miss the opportunity to engage with the SAP Business AI Community to learn from and engage with peers.

Want to dive deeper into the content? Rewatch the sessions and access the session material via SAP Learning Hub (subscription required):

  • Build Your Own AI Solution with Generative AI hub (recording)
  • All Things Business AI: Latest Insights, Updates & Live Demos (recording)

Speaking of the latest insights and updates: Have you read the SAP Business AI Release Highlights Q3 2025 and the SAP Innovation Guide H2 2025, which contain all the innovations announced at SAP TechEd? Highlights include:

  • SAP Joule for Consultants: Consultants can now leverage a new Prompt Guide for quick-start tips and a filterable Prompt Library to browse pre-formulated questions by role or area. Watch a demo of the tool here.
  • Generative AI hub: The open-source coding agent Cline has been integrated into generative AI hub. Learn how to prompt, create and innovate with AI Vibe Coding and see the reference architecture for more information.
  • Joule Studio, agent builder beta release enables business and IT users to create custom AI agents that automate complex, end-to-end business processes. Make sure to register to our upcoming Beyond Hype session demonstrating how to build custom Joule agents in Joule Studio.

Hi Joule, where should I get started with the latest learning resources? *

Apart from live enablement sessions, explore our latest on-demand learning resources:

  • Experience SAP Business AI: Discover the business value SAP Business AI delivers across your business with a practical exercise.
  • Find curated learning and enablement resources across the SAP Business AI portfolio from introductory awareness to getting started and deep-dive content, supporting SAP customers in building the knowledge they need to explore, adopt, and succeed with SAP Business AI solutions: SAP Business AI, Joule, Joule Agents, SAP Joule for Consultants, SAP Joule for Developers, Joule Studio, Generative AI hub, SAP Document AI

* Powered by the machine learning technology of SAP AI Business Services, personalized recommendations are generated for employees, in one place on the Learning home page, based on employee data.

As we look ahead into 2026, we’re excited to share with you a new lineup of learning opportunities designed to help you expand your knowledge and make AI an advantage in your role:

  • January 13, 4 pm CET: Step-by-step guidance to build custom Joule agents in Joule Studio. Understand the exact steps to design and create custom Joule agents.

Stay tuned for more, and happy learning! 🚀

Further Resources:

  • From Hype to Hands-On: Level Up Your AI Skills This October
  • From Hype to Hands-On: Level Up Your AI Skills This November

Joule Joule Studio #generativeaihub #SAPRPT1 #JouleforConsultants #SAPDocumentAI #JouleforDevelopers #AIenablement #AIskills

entry.title: Re: Exchange Rate Difference Postings at Payment Time – A...
entry.content:
Good day @AlvaroFernandezMorales 

Thank you for your question

To summarise, the extra 6680 Dr and 7680 Cr you are seeing is typically a parallel currency balancing effect S/4HANA produces. In public cloud, the system calculates your realised exchange rate differences at payment time, not only for the transaction currency but also per local currency type you have maintained for your company code (for example company code currency, group currency and additional currencies). Because each currency type can use a different rate source or rate, it is possible that, one currency view results in a loss while another view results in a gain or a different amount.

In an effort to keep the journal entry balanced in every currency view, the system may reclassify the loss and gain accounts, in your case 6680 and 7680. This might look like net zero in one currency but it is usually not net zero when you look at the other currency columns. See the following references for more insights: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/89d896ca9cd64318b1667df5ec00e4b2/32915c3a62f3430183ce2dc478742a01.html?locale=en-US & https://learning.sap.com/courses/customizing-core-settings-in-financial-accounting-in-sap-s4hana/managing-exchange-rate-differences

From a functionally perspective:

  • What you see is not the system creating a reversal of the GR or invoice FX difference
  • It is aimed to ensure the document is correct across all currency views when your realised FX differences are calculated at payment time.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: is customer allowed to build custom Odata in ECP base...
entry.content:
Hi, 

I cannot find any restrictions in ECP Service Catalogue to create custom Odata, but in my opinion is not necessary to create new ones.

Cost centers' replication should be done according to the guideline described in the below link:

Overview of Integration Between Employee Central Payroll and SAP S/4HANA Finance | SAP Help Portal

in your case, if I understood properly your landscape scenario, either MDI or ALE could be used.

There is not mention about bank's replication , but I believe you could use the same tool as well.

Finally, I strongly suggest to start using MDI as it is the future of integration!

Best Regards

Giorgio

entry.title: Getting Unconventional with Groovy - Part 1 - Executing Shell commands Reading Trace Files
entry.content:
Getting Unconventional with Groovy - Part 1 - Executing Shell commands Reading Trace Files

 

Requirement - 

Requirement is to read SAP CI http trace logs periodically but the standard LogFiles API returns the entire file which for a tenant with heavy traffic (in millions) can easily go above 100mb.

It therefore becomes impractical to pull http trace file (full file) every 30 second for instance. This is needed for any SIEM solution as http trace file is the only place we get 401, 403 errors.

 

Solution 

Solution is to run Shell command directly onto SAP CI. Here is a simple script that allows you to send in any shell command and executes it and gets the result

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message
import org.apache.karaf.shell.api.console.Session
import org.apache.karaf.shell.api.console.SessionFactory
import org.osgi.framework.BundleContext
import org.osgi.framework.FrameworkUtil
import groovy.json.*

Message processData(Message message) {
    def result = [:]
    try {
        // Parse commands from request body
        def bodyText = message.getBody(String.class)
        def commands = [:]
        
        if (bodyText && bodyText.trim()) {
            try {
                commands = new JsonSlurper().parseText(bodyText)
            } catch (Exception parseEx) {
                // If not JSON, treat as single command
                commands = ["cmd": bodyText.trim()]
            }
        } else {
            result = [error: "No commands provided. Send JSON body like: {\"name\": \"shell:cat /path/to/file\"}"]
            message.setBody(JsonOutput.prettyPrint(JsonOutput.toJson(result)))
            message.setHeader('Content-Type', 'application/json')
            return message
        }
        
        ByteArrayOutputStream out = new ByteArrayOutputStream()
        ByteArrayOutputStream err = new ByteArrayOutputStream()
        BundleContext context = FrameworkUtil.getBundle(Message.class).bundleContext
        SessionFactory sessionFactory = (SessionFactory) context.getService(context.getServiceReference(SessionFactory.class))
        
        def pOut = new PrintStream(out, true, "UTF-8")
        def pErr = new PrintStream(err, true, "UTF-8")
        
        Session session = sessionFactory.create(new ByteArrayInputStream(), pOut, pErr)
        
        def outputs = [:]
        
        commands.each { name, cmd ->
            out.reset()
            err.reset()
            try {
                session.execute(cmd.toString())
                outputs[name] = [
                    output: out.toString("UTF-8").take(50000),
                    error: err.toString("UTF-8")
                ]
            } catch (Exception e) {
                outputs[name] = [error: e.message]
            }
        }
        
        result = outputs
        session.close()
    } catch (Exception ex) {
        result = [
            error: ex.message,
            errorClass: ex.class.name,
            stackTrace: ex.stackTrace.take(5).collect { it.toString() }
        ]
    }
    
    def response = JsonOutput.prettyPrint(JsonOutput.toJson(result))
    message.setBody(response)
    message.setHeader('Content-Type', 'application/json')
    
    return message
}

 

then pass the following in a content modifier placed just before this script

{
  "get_real_traffic_only": "shell:grep -v '/health' log/localhost_access_log.txt",
  
  "get_cxf_endpoints": "shell:grep '/cxf/' log/localhost_access_log.txt"
  

}

        "error": ""
    },

    }
}

to get just the last 10 records use this 

  "get_real_traffic_only_latest": "shell:grep -v '/health' log/localhost_access_log.txt | tail -n 10"

 

Conclusion

 

This demonstrates that everything is possible you just need to find a way to get something done. This ensures you are optimally pulling the http trace logs.

entry.title: Re: SAP IBP Sum up total year in monthly level using key...
entry.content:
Hi Lucas,

 

1. In your sales KF you will probably need to a new line of calculation in order to make sure you are aggregating all products/customers. 

2. After that, use Cumulative Aggregation to sum up the sales - there's an YTD example displayed in the bottom part of the screen, after 5th parameter setup.

entry.title: SAP EWM Podcast - Episode 25 - SAP's new Solution SAP Logistics Management
entry.content:
Welcome to our blog post for the SAP EWM Podcast Episode 25 – SAP's new Solution SAP Logistics Management. You can listen to the podcast episode in English and in German on Spotify, Amazon Music, Apple Podcasts or Sway! Enjoy!

SAP Logistics Management: Filling the Gap Between Simplicity and Complexity

When it comes to warehouse management, SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) has long been the go-to solution for large, complex operations. From massive spare parts warehouses to production supply chains, EWM delivers the depth and sophistication needed to handle demanding logistics environments. But what about the smaller, simpler warehouses? Surprisingly, analysts estimate that nearly one-third of warehouses worldwide are still managed with paper or spreadsheets. For these businesses, EWM can feel overwhelming—too powerful for their needs, too complex for a quick rollout.

This is where SAP’s new solution comes in: SAP Logistics Management.

Why a New Solution?

SAP EWM covers complexity levels 3 to 5, where automation, industry-specific processes, and advanced services are essential. Many customers desire a simplified solution for warehouses of Levels 1 and 2 warehouses — those with basic functions and minimal automation. SAP Logistics Management is designed to offer a streamlined, accessible solution for smaller warehouses or satellite locations that don’t require the full scope of EWM.

More than just Warehouse Management!

While warehouse processes are at the heart of Logistics Management, the solution goes further:

  • Transport Management: It supports scenarios like parcel shipping, less-than-truckload (LTL), and Ex-Works (customer pickup). Full truckload (FTL) capabilities are on the roadmap.

  • Network Integration: Logistics Management connects warehouse and transport processes into a broader logistics ecosystem, ensuring seamless coordination.

 

SAP Logistics Management combines Warehouse Logistics, Transportation Logistics and Network Logistics

 

This combination makes it more than just a “lightweight warehouse tool.” It’s a unified logistics platform for companies with simple needs today but ambitions to grow tomorrow.

Who Benefits?

SAP Logistics Management is tailored for:

  • Smaller businesses with straightforward logistics processes.

  • Large enterprises managing multiple small or satellite warehouses alongside their main EWM-driven hubs.

  • Companies focused on transport first, such as those replacing legacy solutions like WM/Stock Room Management or LE-TRA, with the option to add warehouse functionality later.

Completing the Portfolio

SAP already offers a reduced version of EWM in the S/4HANA Public Cloud, but that solution is integrated only. SAP Logistics Management expands the portfolio by providing a decentralized option that can connect to other ERP systems, including S/4HANA Private Cloud or even SAP ECC. This flexibility ensures that SAP can now support logistics operations across the full spectrum—from paper-based warehouses just starting their digital journey to highly automated global distribution centers.

 

Technical Integration and Future Capabilities

SAP Logistics Management fills the gap between complex and simple warehouses. But complexity isn’t defined only by warehouse size — it’s also about the software requirements. Logistics Management is a full-fledged Warehouse Management System (WMS): it manages storage bins, inbound and outbound processes, deliveries, inventory counts, and more. So how does the technical integration actually work?

Decentralized Architecture

SAP Logistics Management is designed as a decentralized solution. This means it connects to ERP systems via interfaces rather than being embedded directly. Key aspects include:

  • Master data integration: Materials and business partners are transferred, with batch data coming soon.

  • Transactional data: Purchase orders and deliveries are imported via APIs and transformed into “Logistical Demands”—the core documents Logistics Management operates on.

  • Future expansion: Additional ERP documents such as inbound deliveries, customer orders, stock transfers, production orders, and returns will be integrated over time.

ERP Integration Focus

  • Initial focus is on S/4HANA Private Cloud integration.

  • S/4HANA Public Cloud connectivity is planned for Q3 2026.

  • Integration runs through the SAP Integration Suite, ensuring standardized and scalable connectivity.

Functional Scope at First Release

The first general availability release in February 2026 will already cover a wide range of features. However, some capabilities will follow shortly after e.g. Batch management is planned to be available in Q1 202.  Serial numbers are not yet supported at launch, though the inventory model is technically prepared for them. Compared to EWM or TM, Logistics Management will initially have fewer advanced features. But as a true Public Cloud product, it benefits from continuous innovation: new functionalities are delivered every two weeks, without waiting for rigid release cycles.
You can find more information in the SAP Logistics Management Product Documentation. 

AI Support with Joule

A standout feature is the integration of SAP Joule, the AI Copilot. This makes the system easier to learn and use. Users can ask natural-language questions like “Help me create a storage bin” or “Show me today’s deliveries.” No need to memorize transaction codes—the AI assistant guides users through everyday tasks

SAP Logistics Management Home Screen powered by Joule

 

Cloud Extensibility and SAP BTP Foundation

SAP Logistics Management isn’t just about simplifying warehouse operations—it’s also about embracing the Public Cloud mindset. With new interfaces, extensibility options, and a modern architecture, the solution is designed to evolve rapidly while keeping costs and complexity under control.

Extensibility in the Cloud

Flexibility is essential in logistics. SAP Logistics Management offers several ways to extend functionality:

  • APIs: Starting in 2026, SAP will release APIs to enable deeper integration and customization.

  • Key-User Extensibility: Customers can add fields not available in the standard system, a familiar feature from SAP’s public cloud portfolio.

  • Label and List Customization: Layouts for loading lists and labels can already be adjusted, including adding company logos.

Unlike traditional systems, customers no longer access database tables directly (no SE16 or manual SELECT statements). Instead, extensions are handled through APIs, ensuring a Clean Core. This approach makes the bi-weekly updates possible without disrupting customer systems.

Built on SAP BTP

SAP Logistics Management is developed on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), similar to other new solutions like Digital Manufacturing (DM). This has several advantages:

  • Lightweight provisioning: Setting up a Logistics Management instance takes minutes, not hours.

  • Cost efficiency: Running outside the full S/4HANA stack reduces overhead.

  • Continuous innovation: New features are delivered every two weeks. They remain inactive until customers choose to enable them which ensures stable operations of the solution. This model ensures customers benefit from rapid innovation without the burden of constant regression testing.

SAP Logistics Management is not the successor of SAP EWM or SAP TM

A common question is whether SAP Logistics Management replaces EWM (Extended Warehouse Management) or TM (Transportation Management). The answer is clear: No. 
Logistics Management focuses on simpler warehouses and transport scenarios, not large distribution centers or multimodal transport networks. SAP EWM and SAP TM continue to evolve. The recent S/4HANA 2025 release introduced new features, and the roadmap is full of enhancements for future releases. 

SAP’s strategy is complementary: SAP Logistics Management fills the gap for smaller, decentralized operations, while SAP EWM and SAP TM remain the backbone for complex, large-scale logistics.

A New Path for Warehousing and Transport

For retail customers with large distribution centers and complex material flow systems (MFS), the choice is clear: SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM). Likewise, when transport requirements involve multiple modes of transportation or advanced features like route optimization and driver planning, the answer is equally straightforward: SAP Transportation Management (TM).

But many of these same customers also operate smaller warehouses or have simpler transport needs. In these cases, the new SAP Logistics Management (LGM) solution may be the perfect fit.

Imagine a “pop-up” warehouse rented temporarily to handle seasonal demand or additional capacity. With Logistics Management, such a site can be up and running quickly, without the complexity of a full EWM implementation.

Fast and Simple Implementation

One of the key priorities behind Logistics Management was ease of adoption. The system can be provisioned in just a few minutes or may be a few hours. Many processes come pre-configured with default settings, allowing companies to start operations quickly. Customization and optimization can then be added step by step, as requirements evolve.

This makes Logistics Management ideal for organizations that need agility and speed without sacrificing integration into SAP’s broader logistics ecosystem.

First Impressions of SAP Logistics Management

Set Up the solution

Manage your warehouse layout

Manage your day with the help of Joule

 

Run the solution 

Manage Transports and Consignments

 Manage outbound deliveries

Mobile Working with SAP Logistics Management

 Packing at Packing Station with SAP Logistics Management

 Key Takeaways

From SAP’s perspective, the most important points about Logistics Management are:

  • SAP Logistics Management does not replace SAP EWM and SAP TM.

  • Fast and cost-effective implementation is a core strength.

  • Modern user interfaces with full Joule/AI support make the system intuitive.

  • Continuous innovation ensures new features are delivered regularly.

A New Journey in the Public Cloud

SAP Logistics Management marks the beginning of a new journey for warehouse and transport solutions. Every journey starts with a first step—and that step has now been taken. 

With its focus on simplicity, speed, and innovation, Logistics Management promises to be an exciting and successful addition to SAP’s logistics portfolio, complementing SAP EWM and  SAP TM rather than replacing them.

entry.title: SAP Service Cloud -Year 2025 in Review
entry.content:
Reflecting on 2025: celebrating AI-first innovations and customer success

Customer service has always been a balancing act between delivering great experiences and managing the cost to serve. Today, AI is transforming this balance by automating routine tasks, empowering service teams with deeper insights and guided flows and helping organizations elevate customer satisfaction. It’s an exciting moment for the industry, and for SAP Service Cloud.

Looking back, 2025 stands out as a year marked by significant customer go-lives and steady adoption of AI enhanced capabilities. Through their work, our customers are reshaping the future of customer service, and we are privileged to support them on this journey. Döhler is a strong example of a customer leveraging SAP CX and multiple AI capabilities across the organization to drive both customer value and operational efficiency. Also Eurogast is another widely adopting SAP CX to improve customer service and deliver what they call “handshake quality”. 

Advancing SAP Service Cloud with an AI-first strategy

Our AI-first strategy continued to be a key pillar for SAP Service Cloud development, with a focus on embedding AI capabilities across the service journey. The latest AI capabilities automate service operations, simplify case management and provide service reps with actionable insights.


Recent innovations such as business information extraction and duplicate detection streamline agents’ work during case handling by reducing manual data entry, preventing duplicate records, and minimizing errors. The automatic linking of business documents to cases enables automatic initiation of actions that can be performed.   

 

SAP Service Cloud AI Duplicate detection

Account synopsis and visual insights like sentiment trends and the sentiment graph give agents an immediate understanding of a customer's situation and emotional tone, enabling them to respond more quickly and provide more informed, empathetic service.

Once a case is closed, the resolution summary offers service teams a structured view of the resolution steps, key metrics, and customer satisfaction. This helps teams learn from completed cases and continuously improve service quality.

New AI innovations are being developed at an accelerated pace, and new features often emerge even before the ink is dry—so stay tuned for more updates on what’s coming next.


AI agents that scale service operations

The future of customer service will be shaped by AI agents and human agents working seamlessly together. In 2025, we continued to advance this vision by expanding our portfolio of AI agents that accelerate issue resolution and reduce the overall cost to serve, while enhancing the experience for both customers and service teams.

The Case Categorization Agent automatically analyzes incoming tickets and assigns them to the right teams based on learned patterns and best practices. This ensures consistent case handling, reduces the manual effort spent on triage, and allows service experts to focus on the issues where they have the deepest expertise and can deliver the most value.
See how Bosch is accelerating ticket management with SAP Service Cloud and Case Categorization agent.

The Utilities Customer Self-Service Agent supports utilities providers by giving customers easy access to common service features and product offerings through a human-like, conversational experience. By handling high-volume inquiries across multiple channels, it significantly reduces operational costs while maintaining the level of service quality customers expect from human agents. The agent is delivered as an API-only offering, allowing utilities companies to integrate it into a wide range of frontend applications.

The Q&A Agent autonomously processes and answers customer questions using existing enterprise data. It interprets natural-language questions, identifies intent, and responds with accurate information drawn from predefined data sources such as knowledge bases, historical tickets, or case records. Administrators can configure specific question types and ensure the agent delivers reliable, contextual answers that reduce the workload on human agents.

Together, these AI agents help service organizations scale more effectively, maintain service levels during peak periods, and free human agents to focus on complex or sensitive interactions that require deeper expertise and empathy. See a video of the AI agents in action.

More AI agent innovations are already in development, and you can expect additional industry-specific and cross-process agents to be introduced throughout the year.

AI innovations in SAP Service Cloud


Accelerating issue to resolution process with enhanced Case Management

We continue to receive excellent customer feedback on our guided resolution process, which helps service teams navigate cases more efficiently and consistently. In 2025, we expanded the capabilities with several new features that simplify ticket handling and further accelerate resolution.

Improve case categorization with business information extraction

Building on our AI capabilities, case categorization is now more accurate and automated. Business information extraction helps identify key details within case content, improving categorization quality and reducing the manual effort required during initial triage.


Automate follow-up processes with action steps

A new action step allows service teams to trigger the next step in a process—whether it occurs inside SAP Service Cloud or in an external system. Internally, action steps can automate the creation of follow-up items such as subcases or service orders. Externally, action steps can invoke an external hook to call another system directly from the case flow. This brings greater automation and ensures follow-up processes happen consistently and on time.

Focus on what matters most with personalized KPI cards
Service teams can now tailor KPI cards on the home page to surface the metrics most relevant to their daily work. With visualizations such as bar charts, donut charts, and other formats, agents gain clearer insight into priorities, backlog trends, and workload distribution.

SAP Service Cloud KPI cards


Empowering agents with a more connected and insightful workspace

For service teams, it is essential that agents have all relevant information at their fingertips and can efficiently handle customer inquiries across any channel. In 2025, we introduced several enhancements to the Agent Desktop that strengthen omnichannel support and streamline the way agents respond to customer needs.

Amazon Connect chatbot integration
To strengthen self-service capabilities, SAP Service Cloud now integrates with Amazon Connect chatbots. Customers can resolve common inquiries through conversational self-service before ever reaching an agent, reducing wait times and lowering operational effort. When a handover to a human agent is needed, the Agent Desktop provides full chatbot context, allowing agents to pick up the conversation seamlessly without requiring customers to repeat information. This creates a smoother, more efficient experience for both customers and service teams.

Letter interactions
Despite increasing digitalization, letters remain an important communication channel in many industries. Agents can now manage letter-based communications directly within the Agent Desktop, ensuring formal correspondence is handled as seamlessly as digital interactions. With the integration of OpenText Document Presentment Service, agents can quickly create outbound letters using automatically prepopulated fields and brand-aligned templates.

Keep agents informed
Customer Hub provides service agents with the information they need to deliver personalized and efficient experiences. We have added several enhancements to further improve usability and quick access to relevant information. Internal alerts are one example: they notify service reps about payment issues, escalations, or other important customer updates.


End to end issue resolution made easier  

We have enhanced our integration with SAP S/4HANA in many ways, improving visibility and information flow across systems. Wit the recent customer returns integration you can capture the customer return orders and replicate to SAP S/4HANA for further processing, ensuring transparency throughout the process. We have further improved the Service Order integration for a more streamlined inhouse repair process.

The direct integration with SAP Field Service Management streamlines issue resolution from the first contact all the way to scheduling and the onsite fix, helping teams coordinate more effectively and increase first time fix.

We have also enabled URL mashups in case management and service order, making it easier to connect SAP Service Cloud with any systems and processes needed for successful service delivery.

 

Strengthening service capabilities for utilities providers

This year, we introduced a new GenAI-powered Utilities Insights scenario that helps service agents quickly understand key consumption trends for a premise. With AI-generated summaries of consumption graphs, agents can immediately identify usage fluctuations, anomalies, and important patterns—supporting more informed conversations and faster issue resolution for utilities customers.

Beyond AI insights, we also delivered several enhancements that give utilities agents deeper visibility into operational and account-related conditions. Agents can now easily see when a premise is disconnected and, where applicable, initiate a reconnection of AMI meters directly from SAP Service Cloud through seamless integration with SAP S/4HANA. We also added clearer visibility into contract account blocks and contract blocks and locks, enabling agents to understand any restrictions on billing or service processes without switching views.

To simplify navigation and accelerate access to the right information, Utilities Entities are now presented in a hierarchical structure—collective contract account, contract account, premise, and contract—allowing agents to understand customer context at a glance.


Shaping customer service for next year and the years ahead

As we look ahead, the future of customer service will be shaped by human agents and AI agents working seamlessly together. AI will increasingly handle routine tasks, surface insights, and guide service flows, while human experts focus on the complex, empathetic interactions that truly build customer trust. We are excited to continue advancing SAP Service Cloud in this direction, working closely with our customers and partners to deliver innovations that enhance service operations, improve customer experiences, and empower teams to do their best work. Together, we are shaping a new era of intelligent, connected customer service.

entry.title: ‌🇺🇸‌ SAP Sapphire & ASUG Annual Conference Orlando
entry.content:
Experience three days full of opportunities to learn, network, and receive personalized support. Engage directly with our localization experts and partners to discuss strategies, share insights, and explore solutions that help you address regional compliance and business requirements effectively.

entry.title: Re: Understanding the Belgium B2B e-Invoicing Mandate and the Plant Abroad Scenario
entry.content:
This blog is missing a crucial configuration step.

You should select the plants abroad checkbox for messages BE_MESSAGE_PUSH and BE_RESPONSE_PUSH in view EDOMSGTYPEV.

If you don't maintain these messages you will have an error in the Peppol exchange

entry.title: Re: Calculated column in Story report
entry.content:
Hello Wendi, 

While calculated columns will not be possible as they do not work across rows, you can try building a aggregated calculation from the story page.
An aggregated calculated measure might be helpful here.
For a Cross tab widget -> 

  1. Add calculations under measure
  2. Choose calculations of type aggregation
  3. Set the operation to SUM
  4. Add the field you'd like to sum under measure
  5. Add dimension contexts like username and goal ID

Thanks,
Ananya

entry.title: SAP BTP secures a leader’s position on G2 Enterprise Grid®
entry.content:
Reflecting on a busy year for SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) in 2025, it’s clear to see that we’ve had good cause for celebration, having been awarded G2’s much sought-after badges consistently across each quarter of the year. This has culminated only recently with their Winter 2026 awards, where again SAP BTP has received badges as a Leader in the Cloud Platform as a Service (PaaS) category.

But awarding badges to vendors is just one way in which G2 uses the data from customer feedback, while another is to help software buyers in their decision-making process through their quarterly Grid® reports for the various software categories that they cover. These reports, they say, represent the voice of real software users, based on data sourced from product reviews shared by G2 users and are intended to help technology buyers to assess and select the best products for their businesses, based on their peers’ experiences.

A place on the Grid®

As you can see in the recently issued Enterprise Grid® Report for Cloud Platform as a Service (PaaS), SAP BTP has secured a strong position in the Leaders quadrant of this Grid report, which has only been made possible thanks to the incredible feedback from our customers, for which we can only offer our sincere thanks.

What makes SAP BTP different?

The answer to this question is many-fold, as SAP BTP is a software platform comprising a range of technological capabilities. But given this blog concerns the results of customer reviews, rather than offering my opinion, perhaps I’d better leave that to the voice of the customer, so when asked “What do you like about SAP BTP” here’s what two recent reviewers said:

“I like SAP BTP for its seamless integration, ready-to-use services, and flexibility. It helps build, scale, and extend applications quickly while keeping everything connected.” Review posted 26 November 2025

“I like that BTP lets me build and integrate stuff without breaking the core system. Everything’s in one place, it plays nicely with SAP, and it actually works without turning into a mess.” Review posted 29 November 2025

A Badge for all Seasons

As 2025 draws to a close, and we now look forward to 2026, it’s nice to know that we already have our Winter 2026 badges firmly in hand, to step positively into the New Year.

I hope that you similarly have a good close to 2025 and positive start to 2026, and of course please don’t forget to go to the G2 website and take a look at the many SAP BTP reviews available, and if you’re inclined please leave a review yourself.

Chris Grundy, Product Marketing, SAP BTP
